awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Electric-Field-Controlled Nonvolatile Magnetic Memory
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is in addressing the novel hardware challenges of energy and speed associated with big data applications. The electronics industry is quickly transforming from a compute-centric model to a data-centric model, where the key to success in the market place is the ability to store, manipulate and access large amounts of data in a fast and energy-efficient manner.  The existing memory technologies cannot meet these challenges. This changing landscape offers a major potential for emerging memory technologies that can successfully address these new emerging demands.  The Electric-Field-Controlled Nonvolatile Magnetic Memory technology developed under this project offers the most viable low-cost, low-power, and high-endurance solution to these new demands. Conservative estimates project a rapid growth in the emerging memory technologies market, reaching $2B in 2018. We expect that Electric-Field-Controlled Nonvolatile Magnetic Memory will be able to capture a significant part of this emerging market. More broadly, it can be used in many general computing and information processing systems, and hence it can potentially impact a major part of the $300B semiconductors industry by enabling ultra-low power green and instant-on electronic systems.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will focus on the development of prototype Electric-Field-Controlled Nonvolatile Magnetic Memory chips and arrays.  This memory technology uses a fundamentally new way to write information into the nonvolatile memory bits, providing major advantages in terms of power dissipation, cost, density, and scalability. This project will result in chip prototypes, providing significant advantages in terms of energy efficiency, density, and scalability when compared to alternative existing or emerging memory technologies. They also provide virtually unlimited endurance.  Circuit design for memory product development will also be performed, as well as modeling in support of circuit development and device optimization.

por.por_cntn:
Inston’s Magnetoelectric Random Access Memory (MeRAMTM) is positioned to solve the challenges of power dissipation, latency, reliability, endurance and cost of big data. The technology is a novel electric-field controlled magnetic memory (data storage) technology in which the process of writing information is performed using a patented device structure which provides major advantages in power dissipation, cost, density and scalability. For this project, Inston is developing and plans to commercialize MeRAM prototype chips. This includes materials and device development, array fabrication and testing, circuit design and device modeling. The memory technology is targeted for use in big data applications, machine learning, networking and embedded memory.

Under Phase II, Inston successfully developed and demonstrated memory devices (memory bits) based on the MeRAM concept and enhanced a variety of parameters by up to 400%. The functionality has been proven and compared to existing or emerging memory technologies, and has shown to have more than a 10x advantage in energy efficiency and several other key figures of merit. The results will be used to develop MeRAM based memory chips or use in low-power electronics, data intensive computing environments and other markets.

Intellectual Merit:

This project focused on the development of prototype MeRAM chips, arrays, and physical integration with semiconductor-based logic circuitry. During Phase II, we successfully developed, tested and demonstrated the performance of MeRAM bits that are based on Inston’s patented technologies, and have continued to enhance these bits towards the creation of arrays and finally integration within a full semiconductor-based system. We have also fabricated and demonstrated 4kb and 1Mb arrays of our enhanced bits, and have independently designed and taped-out, and tested the semiconductor-based circuitry to drive these memory arrays and have begun the process of integrating our memory using the back-end-of-line (BEOL) manufacturing techniques to realize a fully functional manufacturing line based memory chip. This project has provided significant new insights into the physics and engineering of magnetic nanostructures for data storage and memory. These activities of also included detailed characterization of memory arrays and their electrical performance. Innovations and optimizations of the material stack, fabrication process and circuit designs for writing and reading of these memory bits and arrays towards superior performance and manufacturing compatibility have also been performed.

 

Broader Impact:

The electronics industry is quickly transforming into not only a smart devices model, but also shifting from a compute-centric to data-centric model where the key to success in the market place is the ability to store, manipulate and access large amounts of data in a fast and energy efficient manner. Superior performance and economic viability are now the associated with the delivery of applications and services directly from the cloud with ever increasing demands being places on the underlying technologies used to store information. Current existing memory technologies do not allow for the sustainability of this trend. In the long term, the memory technologies used for big data applications will require greatly lowered power consumption, higher speeds lower costs per bit, higher densities, greater reliability and better scalability to ensure cost-effective storage and reliable retrieval of enormous amounts of data over the next few decades. This shifting landscape of the data industry offers a major opportunity for emerging memory technologies which can successfully address these new upcoming demands. We expect that MeRAM will be able to capture a part of this new market. More broadly, it can be used in general computing and information processing systems, offering a pathway towards instant-on, low latency, ultralow power nonvolatile systems.
